UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
10 
CENTRAL DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA, WESTERN DIVISION 
11 
 
12 
Case No. 5:23-cv-00947-MEMF-BFM 
GARY G., et al., 
 
13 
Plaintiffs,  ORDER DENYING MOTION TO CERTIFY 
14  FOR APPEAL [ECF NO. 80] 
    v.   
15   
 
16 
GAVIN NEWSOM, et al., 
17 
Defendants. 
18 
19      
20   
21   
22  Before the Court is Defendant San Bernardino County’s Motion to Certify for Immediate 
23  Appeal. ECF No. 80. For the reasons stated herein, the Court DENIES the Motion.  
24   
25   
26   
27  / / / 
28  / / /   
 
  1 
 
    
 

Case 5:23-cv-00947-MEMF-BFM     Document 100     Filed 02/12/25     Page 2 of 7   Page ID
#:2265
 
1  I.  Background 
2  The relevant factual background to this case is laid out in the Court’s prior Order Granting in 
3  Part Defendants’ Motion to Dismiss, where the Court denied Defendant San Bernardino County’s 
4  (the “County”) motion to dismiss on the basis of subject matter jurisdiction. ECF No. 78 (“MTD 
5  Order”). On October 11, 2024, the County moved to certify the issue for appeal. ECF No. 80 (the 
6  “Motion”). On January 7, 2025, Plaintiffs filed their opposition. ECF No. 94 (“Opposition”). On 
7  January 14, 2025, the County filed its reply. ECF No. 98 (“Reply”).  
8  II.  Applicable Law 
9  A district court may certify an order for interlocutory appeal when the certification 
10  requirements of 28 U.S.C. § 1292(b) have been met—namely “(1) that there be a controlling 
11  question of law, (2) that there be substantial grounds for difference of opinion, and (3) that an 
12  immediate appeal may materially advance the ultimate termination of the litigation.” In re Cement 
13  Antitrust Litig., 673 F.2d 1020, 1026 (9th Cir. 1981). “[T]he legislative history of 1292(b) indicates 
14  that this section was to be used only in exceptional situations in which allowing an interlocutory 
15  appeal would avoid protracted and expensive litigation.” Id. Indeed, § 1292(b) embodies a “narrow 
16  exception to the final judgment rule.” Couch v. Telescope Inc., 611 F.3d 629, 633 (9th Cir. 2010). 
17  The party pursuing the interlocutory appeal bears the burden of demonstrating that the requirements 
18  established by § 1292(b) are satisfied. Id.  
19  III.  Discussion 
20  The County previously moved to dismiss for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, in part 
21  arguing that the Court should abstain from hearing this action under Younger v. Harris, 401 U.S. 37 
22  (1971).1 See ECF No. 44-1 (“MTD”). In Sprint Commc’ns, Inc. v. Jacobs, the Supreme Court 
23  explained that there are three “exceptional circumstances” that “justify a federal court’s refusal to 
24  decide a case in deference” to: (1) ongoing state criminal prosecutions, (2) certain civil enforcement 
25  proceedings, and (3) pending civil proceedings involving certain orders “uniquely in furtherance of 
26 
 
27 
1 The County also contended that Plaintiffs’ claims are not redressable by federal injunction, and that the 
Rooker-Feldman doctrine deprives the Court of jurisdiction. The Motion does not concern the Court’s ruling 
28 
on these other grounds.   
 
  2 
 
    
 

Case 5:23-cv-00947-MEMF-BFM     Document 100     Filed 02/12/25     Page 3 of 7   Page ID
#:2266
 
1  the state courts’ ability to perform their judicial functions.” 571 U.S. 69, 78 (2013). Where there is 
2  such an exceptional case, courts should still analyze additional factors2 to determine whether 
3  abstention is appropriate. Id. at 81 (explaining that the Middlesex factors are not “dispositive” but 
4  rather “additional factors appropriately considered . . . before invoking Younger”). While the County 
5  contended that Plaintiffs’ ongoing dependency proceedings in state court fall under the second 
6  category of civil enforcement proceedings, the Court found that they did not—and accordingly, there 
7  was no basis to abstain under Younger. MTD Order at 12. As explained next, the Court finds that 
8  while there is a controlling question of law at issue, there are no substantial grounds for difference of 
9  opinion under Ninth Circuit law.   
10  A.  There is a Controlling Question of Law at Issue 
11  First, the Court finds that the issue the County seeks certification of is a question of law. 
12  Although Plaintiffs dispute that the question of Younger abstention is a “pure” question of law, they 
13  cite no binding authority that states that only “pure” questions of law, as opposed to mixed questions 
14  of law and fact, can be certified for appeal. Opposition at 7–8.3 Regardless, even if there were 
15  hypothetical scenarios that could make the abstention analysis fact-intensive, here, the Court did not 
16  rely on any factual basis in making its finding—rather, its analysis focused on the applicable case 
17  law. See MTD Order at 11–12; cf. ICTSI Or., Inc. v. Int’l Longshore & Warehouse Union, 22 F.4th 
18  1125, 1132 (9th Cir. 2022) (finding the dispute a question of fact where “the district court primarily 
19  relied on facts from the record”). Significantly, the issue of abstention is consistently reviewed de 
20 
 
21 
2 In particular, abstention is appropriate where (1) “there is an ongoing state judicial proceeding,” (2) “those 
22 
proceedings implicate important state interests,” (3) “there is adequate opportunity in the state proceedings to 
raise constitutional challenges,” and (4) the “requested relief must seek to enjoin—or have the practical effect 
23 
of enjoining—ongoing state proceedings.” ReadyLink Healthcare, Inc. v. State Comp. Ins. Fund, 754 F.3d 
754, 758 (9th Cir. 2014). These factors are known as the Middlesex factors. See Middlesex Cnty. Ethics 
24 
Comm. v. Garden State Bar Ass’n, 457 U.S. 423 (1982).   
25  3 Plaintiffs cite to a district court case, TCL Communs. Tech. Holdings, Ltd. v. Telefonaktenbologet LM 
Ericsson, for this proposition. 2014 WL 12588293 (C.D. Cal. Sept. 30, 2014). However, this language 
26 
actually appears to stem from a Seventh Circuit Case, where the court explained that a “pure question of law” 
was “something the court of appeals could decide quickly and cleanly without having to study the record.” 
27 
Ahrenholz v. Bd. of Trs. of Univ. of Ill., 219 F.3d 674, 677 (7th Cir. 2000). The Seventh Circuit did not say 
mixed questions of fact and law could never be certified, but merely distinguished between an “abstract legal 
28 
issue” and the “issue of whether summary judgment should be granted.” Id. at 677. 
 
  3 
 
    
 

Case 5:23-cv-00947-MEMF-BFM     Document 100     Filed 02/12/25     Page 4 of 7   Page ID
#:2267
 
1  novo as a question of law on appeals, even in contexts where the Ninth Circuit has decided there is a 
2  mixed question of fact and law. See Commc’ns Telesystems Int’l v. Cal. Public Utility Comm’n, 196 
3  F.3d 1011, 1015 (9th Cir. 1999) (“We review a decision to abstain under Younger as a question of 
4  law.”); Fresh Int’l Corp. v. Agric. Labor Relations Bd., 805 F.2d 1353, 1356 (9th Cir. 1986) (noting 
5  that while the abstention inquiry, including the actual application of the Middlesex factors, “is a 
6  mixed question of fact and law . . . we review de novo a district court’s refusal to abstain under 
7  Younger”). Accordingly, the Court finds the issue to be a question of law.  
8  The Court also finds that this question of law is controlling. The Ninth Circuit has explained 
9  that “all that must be shown in order for a question to be ‘controlling’ is that resolution of the appeal 
10  could materially affect the outcome of litigation in the district court.” In re Cement, 673 F.2d at 
11  1026. A question of jurisdiction undoubtedly materially affects the outcome of this litigation, as the 
12  lack thereof precludes the Court from hearing the case in its entirety. See id. at 1026–27 (noting that 
13  a question of privilege “involves nothing as fundamental as the determination as . . . whether a court 
14  . . . has jurisdiction”). Therefore, the Court finds the first requirement of certification met.  
15  B.  The Court Does Not Find a Substantial Grounds for Difference of Opinion 
16  “To determine if a ‘substantial ground for difference of opinion’ exists under § 1292(b), 
17  courts must examine to what extent the controlling law is unclear.” Couch v. Telescope Inc., 611 
18  F.3d 629, 633 (9th Cir. 2010). “Courts traditionally will find that a substantial ground for difference 
19  of opinion exists where ‘the circuits are in dispute on the question and the court of appeals of the 
20  circuit has not spoken on the point . . .’” Id. The Court acknowledged in its prior ruling that there 
21  was a circuit split on “whether Younger abstention applies in the context of ongoing dependency 
22  proceedings” and that the Ninth Circuit has not spoken on this issue. MTD Order at 11–12. 
23  However, the Court does not find that the circuit split alone provides substantial grounds for a 
24  difference of opinion when considering the existing Ninth Circuit precedent.4  
25   
26  4 Although the County contends that “[t]wo district judges within the Ninth Circuit have found that reasonable 
jurists could reach different conclusions on this exact issue,” it is worth noting that these judges actually made 
27  a finding on this issue consistent with this Court’s, reflecting no substantial difference of opinion within this 
circuit. Reply at 6; see Jeremiah M. v. Crum, 695 F. Supp. 3d 1060, 1079 (D. Alaska 2023) (finding ongoing 
28 
 
 
  4 
 
    
 

Case 5:23-cv-00947-MEMF-BFM     Document 100     Filed 02/12/25     Page 5 of 7   Page ID
#:2268
 
1  First, the Court notes that the Ninth Circuit has explicitly emphasized the parts of Sprint 
2  Communications that this Court relied on in its analysis in ReadyLink Healthcare. In particular, the 
3  Ninth Circuit explained that Sprint “squarely [held] that Younger abstention is limited to the ‘three 
4  exceptional categories’ of cases identified . . .” ReadyLink Healthcare, Inc., 754 F.3d 754, 759 (9th 
5  Cir. 2014). The Ninth Circuit also emphasized that “[f]or civil enforcement actions that are akin to 
6  criminal proceedings . . . the proceedings are characteristically initiated to sanction the federal 
7  plaintiff . . . for some wrongful act, and investigations are commonly involved, often culminating in 
8  the filing of a formal complaint or charges.” Id. (internal quotations omitted). As the Court noted in 
9  its analysis, the dependency proceedings at issue “are not punitive nor criminal.” MTD Order at 10. 
10  Therefore, finding that the dependency proceedings do not fall under the category of civil 
11  enforcement proceedings is consistent with the precedent as reemphasized by the Ninth Circuit. 
12  Moreover, the Court notes that the only binding authority cited by the County that supported 
13  finding otherwise was in the Supreme Court’s decision in Moore v. Sims, 442 U.S. 415, 423 (1979). 
14  See ECF No. 44-1 at 17–18. The Court acknowledged that in Moore, the Supreme Court did find a 
15  state proceeding involving the temporary removal of a child subject to abstention as a quasi-criminal 
16  proceeding. MTD Order at 11. However, the Court distinguished Moore through its interpretation of 
17  Sprint and found that the ongoing dependency proceedings are not analogous to the proceedings at 
18  issue in Moore, which were about the initial removal. Id. To the extent that Moore provided any 
19  grounds for disagreement with the Court’s holding, the Court finds that the Ninth Circuit’s holding 
20  in L.H. v. Jamieson forecloses these grounds. 643 F.2d 1351 (9th Cir. 1981).5 Although L.H. did not 
21  specifically address the issue of whether dependency proceedings should be considered quasi-
22   
23  dependency proceedings “not quasi-criminal proceedings under Younger”); Ocean S. v. Los Angeles County, 
2024 WL 3973047, at *8 (C.D. Cal. June 11, 2024) (“That an initial removal hearing necessarily precedes 
24  hearings in a juvenile court proceeding does not compel the conclusion that the entire dependency proceeding 
is a quasi-criminal action.”).  
25 
Further, in Crum, although the district court certified the Younger abstention question for interlocutory 
26  appeal, the Ninth Circuit ultimately denied the Defendants permission to appeal. See Jeremiah M. v. Kovol, 
Case No. 23-2726, ECF No. 11.1 (9th Cir. Dec. 18, 2023). There is no reason to believe that a request to 
27  appeal here would yield a different result given the similarity of the questions and the applicable standard. 
5 Although the County states that Plaintiffs did not cite L.H. in its opposition to the motion to dismiss, the 
28 
Court notes Plaintiffs did cite it. See ECF No. 53 at 8, 11.   
 
  5 
 
    
 

Case 5:23-cv-00947-MEMF-BFM     Document 100     Filed 02/12/25     Page 6 of 7   Page ID
#:2269
 
1  criminal civil enforcement proceedings and cannot be binding on this point, significantly, L.H. was 
2  decide two years after Moore. Therefore, the Ninth Circuit in L.H. did not find Moore to be a bar in 
3  finding that Younger abstention did not apply to ongoing dependency proceedings.6 Id. at 1352 
4  (reversing district court finding that “the state courts’ continuing jurisdiction over [dependent 
5  children after an initial placement has been made] caused the case to fall within [Younger]”).7 
6  Regardless of the fact that L.H. did not apply the post-Sprint analysis of Younger abstention, at a 
7  minimum, L.H. has the effect of limiting any precedential value Moore has on this issue.  
8  As a result, although the County contends that there is a circuit split as to the scope and 
9  impact of Moore, the Ninth Circuit has specifically not interpreted Moore “to require federal courts 
10  to abstain from any federal action seeking to bring about foster care reform.” See Motion at 12. The 
11  remaining binding authority on this issue as set forth by Sprint and reiterated by the Ninth Circuit 
12  make clear that to be considered a quasi-criminal proceeding, the proceeding must be “akin” to a 
13  criminal one. Here, there is no substantial grounds for dispute that the dependency proceedings at 
14  issue are not akin to criminal proceedings. Accordingly, the Court does not find the second 
15  requirement for certification met.  
16  C.  An Appeal May or May Not Advance the Ultimate Termination of the Litigation 
17  The final prong of certification “is satisfied when the resolution of the question ‘may 
18  appreciably shorten the time, effort, or expense of conducting’ the district court proceedings.” ICTSI 
19 
 
20  6 The County attempts to distinguish L.H. because it involved the role of Arizona state courts and the Ninth 
Circuit noted that the “state court has completed its work once it has made its initial placement decision” in its 
21 
opinion. Id. at 1354. However, the Ninth Circuit was clear that the Arizona courts “retain jurisdiction over 
delinquent and dependent children after an initial placement has been made.” Id. at 1352 (emphasis added).  
22 
7 While the Court did not find it necessary to reach the Middlesex factors given its finding that the dependency 
23  proceedings were not the type of case to which Younger abstention applied, to the extent that the Ninth 
Circuit reversed this decision, the Middlesex factors must still be satisfied in order to find abstention 
24  appropriate. Here, it is worth noting that while L.H.’s analysis was limited to the case law at that time 
surrounding Younger abstention, its analysis is still precedential to the extent that it aligns with what the 
25 
Middlesex factors are today. In particular, whether there is an ongoing state proceeding, whether there is an 
adequate opportunity to raise the challenges in the underlying proceeding, and whether the requested relief 
26 
effectively seeks to enjoin the state proceeding—all factors discussed in L.H.—are still relevant to the current 
Middlesex factors. Moreover, as the County would have to show that all the Middlesex factors are met in 
27 
order for a court to find abstention, L.H.’s finding that some of these factors are not met with regards to 
ongoing dependency proceedings indicates that the outcome here would not be changed even if the Ninth 
28 
Circuit held that the proceedings qualify as quasi-criminal civil enforcement actions.  
 
  6 
 
    
 

Case 5:23-cv-00947-MEMF-BFM     Document 100     Filed 02/12/25     Page 7 of 7   Page ID
#:2270
1  Or., Inc., 22 F.4th at 1131. Here, it is true that if the Ninth Circuit were to find ongoing dependency 
2  proceedings a category of cases subject to Younger abstention, and if the Ninth Circuit or this Court 
3  were to reach the Middlesex factors and find abstention warranted, the case would terminate.8
4  However, to the extent that the Ninth Circuit were to find otherwise, this appeal does not advance 
5  the termination of the case in any way, and in fact significantly delays the ultimate resolution of this 
6  case. Any order related to a finding of subject matter jurisdiction would ultimately shorten the time, 
7  effort, or expense of conducting the proceeding, but the County cites no authority requiring the 
8  automatic certification of a jurisdictional issue. And, even if the Court were to find this final 
9  requirement for certification met, it is insufficient to find certification proper where the Court has not 
10  found a substantial grounds for difference of opinion.  
11  IV. Conclusion 
12  Having reviewed all the factors, the Court in its discretion denies certification of its MTD 
13  Order for appeal. Accordingly, the Court hereby DENIES the Motion to Certify. ECF No. 80. 
14 
15    IT IS SO ORDERED.     
16 
17  Dated: February 12, 2025  ___________________________________ 
18    HON. MAAME EWUSI-MENSAH FRIMPONG 
19    United States District Judge 
20 
21 
22 
23 
24 
25 
26 
27 
8 But the fact that the Ninth Circuit in Crum denied permission to appeal on this precise question suggests that 
perhaps the Ninth Circuit did not find any difference in opinion substantial enough to warrant granting 
28 
permission and that this outcome is unlikely.  
7

Case 5:23-cv-00947-MEMF-BFM     Document 34     Filed 08/14/23     Page 6 of 69   Page ID
#:151
 
1  PRELIMINARY STATEMENT 
2  1.  For more than a decade, Defendants have been in the spotlight for 
3  operating a foster care system in San Bernardino County (“County”) that fails to 
4  protect the foster children whose lives and wellbeing depend on it. 
5  2.  Foster  children  are  being  abused  under  the  supervision  of  San 
6  Bernardino’s Child and Family Services (“CFS”), which runs the County’s foster 
7  care system. In December 2022, the San Bernardino Civil Grand Jury (“Grand Jury”) 
8  investigating CFS concluded that the San Bernardino child welfare system is so 
9  “complicated, secretive, and inefficient” that it is “too broken to fix” and should be 
10  “abolished.” 
11  3.  The United States and California Constitutions and federal and state 
12  statutes impose affirmative duties on CFS and the California Department of Social 
13  Services  (“CDSS”),  the  state  agency  responsible  for  overseeing  CFS,  which 
14  Defendants have systematically failed  to meet in operating and  overseeing the 
15  County’s foster care system. 
16  4.  Specifically, Defendants must protect foster children in CFS’s custody 
17  from harm and provide them with services necessary to ensure their wellbeing in the 
18  least restrictive environment.  
19  5.  This requires Defendants to provide foster children with appropriate 
20  placements that conform to nationally recommended professional standards and 
21  adequately monitor and support foster children after placement.  
22  6.  Defendants must also timely develop, regularly update, and effectively 
23  implement a written case plan for each foster child in CFS’s custody and identify an 
24  appropriate  permanent  home  for  foster  children  within  a  reasonable  period, 
25  including  by  petitioning  for termination  of  parental  rights  within  a  statutorily-
26  mandated timeframe. 
27 
28 
  -6-   
 
  FIRST AMENDE COMPLAINT 
 

Case 5:23-cv-00947-MEMF-BFM     Document 34     Filed 08/14/23     Page 7 of 69   Page ID
#:152
 
1  7.  State and federal laws also require that Defendants provide effective 
2  services  to  foster  children  with  disabilities  to  ensure  they  are  afforded  equal 
3  opportunity and have access to the least restrictive and integrated setting appropriate 
4  to their needs. 
5  8.  Despite  these  clear  constitutional  and  statutory  mandates,  all 
6  Defendants, including CDSS,  have systematically failed to protect foster children 
7  in  San  Bernardino  from  harm  or  ensure  that  they  are  provided  with  services 
8  necessary under the law to ensure their wellbeing in the least restrictive environment.  
9  9.  On Defendants’ watch, Plaintiffs—foster children in the custody of 
10  CFS—have been put in inadequate and often dangerous placements, left without 
11  necessary services, and forced to languish unnecessarily in foster care for years.  
12  10.  CFS has operated and continues to operate without regard to reasonable 
13  professional standards and has exhibited deliberate indifference to the ongoing harm 
14  it inflicts on foster children. CDSS has failed to take the necessary steps to ensure 
15  that CFS protects these children. 
16  11.  The named Plaintiffs—Gary G., Xander B., Francesca B., Delilah B., 
17  Teddy H., Kevin E., Sam E., Henry P., David O., Greg R., and Arnold O.—are all 
18  children in CFS’s custody who have suffered harm at the hands of CFS. They bring 
19  this lawsuit on behalf of all children who are now, or will be, in the custody of CFS. 
20  12.  Plaintiffs’  injuries  were  caused,  and  are  being  caused,  by  CFS’s 
21  numerous policies and practices that violate the rights of foster children protected 
22  by state and federal statutes and safeguarded by the United States and California 
23  Constitutions. CDSS has not taken actions to stop these illegal activities.  
24  13.  For example, CFS does not adequately vet foster homes before placing 
25  children, such as Plaintiffs, in them. In fact, CFS even lacks proper procedures and 
26  practices to screen out known abusers from serving as foster parents. 
27 
28 
  -7-   
 
  FIRST AMENDE COMPLAINT 
 

Case 5:23-cv-00947-MEMF-BFM     Document 34     Filed 08/14/23     Page 8 of 69   Page ID
#:153
 
1  14.  Once  CFS  places  foster  children  in  foster  homes,  it  also  fails  to 
2  adequately monitor the foster children to ensure their safety. Caseworkers fail to 
3  make enough home visits to determine whether foster children are safe in their 
4  placements, as they must under federal and state laws. Moreover, the home visits 
5  that do occur are often perfunctory and do not include separate interviews with the 
6  children in line with professional standards. 
7  15.  CFS also does not provide adequate case planning for Plaintiffs or the 
8  other foster children in its custody. CFS does not conduct timely Child and Family 
9  Team (“CFT”) meetings or provide children, foster parents, and family members 
10  with individualized case plans, as expressly required under federal and state laws. 
11  16.  CFS also lacks adequate short-term emergency placements for foster 
12  children who need them. When children like Plaintiffs enter CFS’s custody, they are 
13  often  forced  to  sleep  on  floors  in  CFS’s  office  for  days  on  end  while  their 
14  caseworkers scramble to find appropriate placements. CFS often ends up placing 
15  foster children with families who do not speak the same language. 
16  17.  Defendants further permit CFS’s caseworkers to carry caseloads that 
17  are too high to possibly meet the standards they must satisfy under the law. In fact, 
18  CFS’s caseworkers often carry caseloads five or six times higher than national 
19  professional standards recommend. Caseworkers with such high caseloads cannot 
20  adequately document and implement each foster child’s case plan as mandated by 
21  federal and state laws.  
22  18.  CFS also does not provide Plaintiffs  or other foster children in its 
23  custody with timely health or dental assessments. When CFS moves foster children 
24  between placements, the new foster parents often do not receive their new foster 
25  child’s health files or documentation regarding their medical and psychological 
26  needs. As a result, foster children fall behind on necessary services and treatments, 
27 
28 
  -8-   
 
  FIRST AMENDE COMPLAINT 
 

Case 5:23-cv-00947-MEMF-BFM     Document 34     Filed 08/14/23     Page 9 of 69   Page ID
#:154
 
1  sometimes left without required medication or essential therapy necessary to address 
2  their traumas and needs. 
3  19.  CFS’s systemic deficiencies expose Plaintiffs, and all foster children in 
4  the County, to a severe risk of maltreatment and future harm. 
5  20.  CFS’s policies and practices disproportionately harm foster children 
6  with  disabilities,  who  are  entitled  to  reasonable  accommodations  under  the 
7  Americans with Disabilities Act and related federal and state statutes. 
8  21.  Fully  aware  of  CFS’s  systematic  failings,  CDSS  and  the  other 
9  Defendants named in this First Amended Complaint have stood by and failed to 
10  exercise appropriate oversight, despite their legal obligation to do so. 
11  22.  Plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief against Defendants to 
12  end  the  ongoing  harm  and  severe  risk  of future  harm  to  which  Plaintiffs  and 
13  thousands of other children in San Bernardino County are subjected on a daily basis. 
14  This lawsuit aims to reform CFS and provide the County’s vulnerable foster children 
15  with the protection, oversight, and services they are entitled to under federal and 
16  state laws. 
17  JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
18  23.  This action arises under the Constitution and laws of the United States, 
19  including 42 U.S.C. § 1983. The Court has jurisdiction over the federal claims under 
20  28 U.S.C. §§ 1331 and 1343(a). The Court may exercise supplemental jurisdiction 
21  over the claims based on California law under 28 U.S.C. § 1367(a). 
22  24.  This Court has jurisdiction to issue declaratory and injunctive relief 
23  under 28 U.S.C. §§ 2201 and 2202 and Rule 57 of the Federal Rules of Civil 
24  Procedure. 
25  25.  Venue  in  this  district  is  proper  under  28  U.S.C.  §  1391(b).  The 
26  divisional venue is appropriate in the Riverside Division because a substantial part 
27 
28 
  -9-   
 
  FIRST AMENDE COMPLAINT 
 

Case 5:23-cv-00947-MEMF-BFM     Document 34     Filed 08/14/23     Page 10 of 69   Page
ID #:155
 
1  of the acts, events, or omissions giving rise to the claims  outlined in the First 
2  Amended Complaint occurred in the Riverside Division. 
3  PARTIES 
4  I.  NAMED PLAINTIFFS 
5  A.  Gary G.1 
6  26.  Gary G. (age 15 months) was born on December 8, 2021, in Apple 
7  Valley, California. He has been in CFS’s custody since December 23, 2021. He lives 
8  in a Foster Family Agency (“FFA”)-licensed foster home in Hesperia, California. 
9  He is a member of the General Class and ADA Subclass. 
10  27.  Gary G. appears through his next friend, Mary Downey. Ms. Downey 
11  has served as Gary G.’s alternate caregiver since he first entered foster care. She 
12  cares for him around three times per week when Gary G.’s primary caregiver is 
13  unavailable. She is also familiar with Gary G.’s history and is dedicated to his best 
14  interests. 
15  B.  Xander B., Francesca B., and Delilah B. 
16  28.  Xander B. (age 12 years) was born on August 26, 2010, in California. 
17  He has been in CFS’s custody since early 2016. He currently lives in a group home 
18  in  Chino  County,  California.  He  is  a  member  of the  General  Class  and  ADA

1  FACTS 
2  I.  CFS ENGAGES IN NUMEROUS POLICIES AND/OR PRACTICES 
3  THAT VIOLATE THE RIGHTS OF FOSTER CHILDREN IN SAN 
4  BERNARDINO COUNTY AND EXPOSE THEM TO A SEVERE 
5  RISK OF FUTURE HARM 
6  A.  CFS Has Spent the Last Decade Embroiled in Controversy 
7  55.  The San Bernardino Grand Jury “is an independent civil watchdog 
8  agency that investigates County agencies, towns and cities, and special districts 
9  within San Bernardino County,” in line with California Penal Code, section 925. 
10  56.  For most of the past decade, the Grand Jury has investigated CFS, and 
11  each year it has done so “it has discovered problems and issues.” For example, the 
12  Grand Jury concluded in 2016 that CFS caseworkers have “heavy caseloads” and 
13  “tremendous turnover.” 
14  57.  In 2017, the Grand Jury noted that caseloads remained “excessively 
15  high, especially in the High Desert.” In 2019, the Grand Jury further reiterated that 
16  “[e]xtremely heavy caseloads are especially a problem because of under-staffing and 
17  an increase in growth of the San Bernardino County’s population.” The 2016 and 
18  2019 reports also noted high caseworker turnover. 
19  58.  During that period, CFS was made further aware of these problems 
20  through litigation and investigative reporting. In fact, Fox News aired a multi-part 
21  exposé on CFS titled “The Children are Dying” in 2015. 
22  59.  In 2022, the Grand Jury found that the average caseworker caseload is 
23  around 70 to 90 cases per worker, that “substantiated foster children abuse cases 
24  have increased  every year from 2019  through 2021,”  and  that the  number “of 
25  substantiated sexual abuse and physical abuse cases is eye-opening.” 
26  60.  The Grand Jury concluded that CFS is so “complicated, secretive, and 
27  inefficient” that it is “too broken to fix” and should be “abolished.” 
28

1  61.  The Grand Jury’s reports are only the latest in a series of investigations 
2  into Defendants’ long-standing failure to operate a foster care system that protects 
3  the foster children whose lives and wellbeing depend on it. The California Attorney 
4  General has investigated “potential systemic breakdowns.” Investigative journalists 
5  have also revealed that foster children have been abused under CFS’s supervision. 
6  Former caseworkers have even reported that CFS has placed foster children with 
7  known sexual predators.  
8  B.  CFS Fails  to Adequately Vet Foster Homes or  Monitor  Foster 
9  Children Once Placed 
10  62.  When  CFS  assumes legal  custody  of  children,  CFS  is  required  to 
11  monitor them to properly ensure their safety and wellbeing. 
12  63.  Part of this responsibility involves properly vetting foster parents, foster 
13  homes, and their inhabitants before entrusting foster children to their care. However, 
14  the Grand Jury has found that “CFS has no comprehensive and complete background 
15  check/vetting  system  for”  foster  parents  and  foster  homes.  As  a  result, 
16  “[b]ackground  checks  of  [foster  homes]  often  miss  unknown  or  undisclosed 
17  boyfriends or relatives who visit the home.” In extreme cases, CFS has even placed 
18  children  with  known,  registered  sex  offenders.  The  Grand  Jury  found  these 
19  procedures “subject foster children to abusive settings.” 
20  64.  Another  part  of  this  responsibility  requires  CFS’s  caseworkers  to 
21  regularly—and thoroughly—visit foster homes to ensure the foster children living 
22  there are safe.  In fact, caseworkers must visit foster children face-to-face at least 
23  once per month, and more than half of these visits should occur at the foster home. 
24  And, during these visits, foster children must receive personalized attention from 
25  their caseworker. If this does not happen, foster parents can “hide abuse problems,” 
26  leading to “substantiated sexual and physical abuses to foster children.” 
27

1  65.  Despite these risks, the Grand Jury has found that caseworkers “do not 
2  visit all children  monthly . . . and  there  are  insufficient and  inadequate  home 
3  inspections during visits.” Indeed, caseworkers often conduct “fly-by” visits without 
4  “interview[ing] the child or look[ing] into rooms or closets.” The Grand Jury found 
5  “that these brief interviews [] led to substantiated abuse cases.” 
6  66.  CFS’s lack of adequate vetting procedures for foster homes and failure 
7  to ensure caseworkers conduct appropriate visits to children in their placements 
8  leave foster children at substantial risk of experiencing harm and maltreatment in 
9  care. 
10  C.  CFS Does Not Provide Adequate Case Planning 
11  67.  Federal law requires CFS to provide foster children with a detailed, 
12  individualized case plan. These plans are necessary to effectively engage family 
13  members and tailor services to adequately address their needs and the needs of their 
14  children. CFS must also periodically review these case plans—at least once every 
15  six months—until a child’s case is resolved and the child has been discharged from 
16  custody.  
17  68.  Federal and state law require that “[a] written case plan [] be completed 
18  within a maximum of 60 days of the initial removal of the child.” The case plan must 
19  include,  among  other  things,  “[b]ehaviorally  specific  goals  and  objectives  and 
20  services that will help the parents achieve a safe home for the child,” a “[s]chedule 
21  of  the  social  worker  (SW)  contacts  with  the  child,  family,  and  caregivers,” 
22  “[p]ermanency plans,” and “[a]ssurances of educational stability while the child is 
23  in out-of-home care.” 
24  69.  State law further requires that foster children over 12 years old “be 
25  given the opportunity to participate in the development of his/her case plan, review, 
26  sign and receive a copy of the case plan.” 
27 
28

1  70.  CFS’s own internal policy handbook adds that the caseworker “should 
2  involve  the  parent(s),  child  and/or  additional  family  and  community  resource 
3  persons in the development of the case plan.” This policy emphasizes a shift “from 
4  the [caseworker] dictating the case plan to the parents and/or children to a more 
5  collaborative effort where the [caseworker] encourages their participation in the 
6  development of the case plan.” 
7  71.  CFT meetings represent one tool for caseworkers to collaborate with 
8  parents and children in case planning. CFT meetings should include foster children, 
9  their  family  members,  professionals,  natural  community  supports,  and  other 
10  individuals invested in the child’s success. 
11  72.  These meetings must occur within 60 days of a child’s entry into foster 
12  care, at least once every six months thereafter for children not receiving specialized 
13  mental health services, and at least once every 90 days for children receiving such 
14  specialized care. 
15  73.  All available evidence indicates that, despite statutory requirements, 
16  CFS’s caseworkers do not complete case plans on time or with all the required 
17  information,  and  CFT  meetings  do  not  occur  on  time  with  all  the  necessary 
18  stakeholders. 
19  74.  In a 2017 County Self-Assessment, CFS observed that families’ “voices 
20  are not being heard.” In essence, case plans are “cookie cutter,” “not update[d] . . . 
21  [to reflect the child’s] progress and new needs,” and “not tailored to the family and 
22  child’s needs.” At the same time, CFS reflected on a “[n]eed for more CFTs—
23  routinely.” Above all, CFS noted that caseworkers’ lack of engagement stemmed 
24  from high caseloads, which inhibited caseworkers’ “ability to engage in ongoing 
25  assessment[s].” 
26  75.  Many foster parents, family members, and foster children have never 
27  seen the foster child’s case plan.

1  76.  What  is  more,  CFS  caseworkers  are  not  conducting  timely  CFT 
2  meetings. And, when they do, caseworkers do not show or discuss the foster child’s

4  77.  Finally,  CFS  has  observed  several  other issues  interfering  with  its 
5  caseworkers’ ability to connect with foster children and their biological and foster 
6  families. First, CFS’s caseworkers often “do not speak the same language as the 
7  family.” Second, CFS noticed its caseworkers “were quick to label parent[s] as 
8  ‘resistant.’”  And  third,  CFS  found  that  its  caseworkers  were “missing  cultural 
9  humility and trauma-informed components to providing services.” 
10  78.  CFS’s lack of timely, appropriate case planning, by itself, places foster 
11  children at risk of serious and ongoing harm. This serious risk is aggravated by the 
12  fact that CFS does not regularly include all required stakeholders, such as relatives, 
13  foster parents, and family friends in the case planning process. At bottom, these 
14  issues prevent CFS from evaluating foster children’s service needs and effectively 
15  planning for permanency as the law requires. 
16  D.  CFS Lacks Short-Term Emergency Placements 
17  79.  Federal law and widely accepted professional standards require CFS to 
18  place each foster child in the most appropriate and least restrictive placement that 
19  best  suits  the  child’s  needs.  See  42  U.S.C.  §  622(b)(8)(A)(iii);  42  U.S.C.  § 
20  675(5)(A). Extensive child welfare literature also emphasizes the need to choose 
21  each child’s placement based on all information available about the child and the 
22  need to consider all available information carefully. 
23  80.  This means that CFS must have an adequate array of placements to 
24  properly  accommodate  foster  children  with  varying  levels  of  needs.  And,  by 
25  extension, CFS must properly assess each foster child’s needs before placing them 
26  with a foster family or facility, matching them with particular homes and facilities 
27  based on fit rather than availability. 
28

1  81.  Despite these requirements, CFS lacks adequate short-term emergency 
2  placements for children, so when children first enter care, CFS often has no other 
3  placement for them than a local CFS office. The Grand Jury found that foster 
4  children remain in these offices for “days or weeks at a time.” 
5  82.  CFS recently acknowledged that “[a] certain number of children and 
6  youth, particularly those with complex needs and significant behavioral/emotional 
7  problems, spend nights in [CFS] offices.” 
8  83.  These  offices  lack  essentials  such  as  proper  beds,  bathrooms,  and 
9  kitchens. Consequently, children “sleep on the floor, cots, and other locations” and 
10  eat from “fast food restaurants” that lack nutritional value. What is more, children 
11  with special needs often cannot receive any of their medication or other necessary 
12  services.
